Introductory statement Mario Draghi to the press conference https://t.co/XDMbxi5o64
Draghi: [10 years after the crisis] All in all the banks are stronger today. So can we be complacent? No, especially as lots of business has migrated from banks to non-banks.
Draghi: Major source of uncertainty we see in global outlook comes from rising protectionism
Draghi: The mandate of the ECB is price stability in the medium term and QE is one of the tools we have used to pursue that task

Draghi: The transparent and consistent implementation of the EU’s fiscal and economic governance framework over time and across countries remains essential to bolster the resilience of the euro area economy

Draghi: The broad-based expansion calls for rebuilding fiscal buffers. This is particularly important in countries where government debt is high and for which full adherence to the Stability and Growth Pact is critical for safeguarding sound fiscal positions.
Draghi: Other policy areas must contribute more decisively to raising the longer-term growth potential and reducing vulnerabilities
Draghi introduces the GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area https://t.co/JbPJ5e3fTY
Draghi: Risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook can still be assessed as broadly balanced

Draghi: Our monetary policy measures continue to underpin domestic demand. Private consumption is supported by ongoing employment gains, which, in turn, partly reflect past labour market reforms, and by rising wages.
Draghi: At the same time, uncertainties relating to rising protectionism, vulnerabilities in emerging markets and financial market volatility have gained more prominence recently

Draghi: The underlying strength of the economy continues to support our confidence that the sustained convergence of inflation towards our aim will proceed and will be maintained even after a gradual winding-down of our net asset purchases

Draghi: The incoming information, including our new September 2018 staff projections, broadly confirms our previous assessment of an ongoing broad-based expansion of the euro area economy and gradually rising inflation

Draghi: We will reduce the monthly pace of the net asset purchases to €15 billion until the end of December 2018 and we anticipate that, subject to incoming data confirming our medium-term inflation outlook, we will then end net purchases

@BedrosGesaratsi The Governing Council of the ECB may decide to withdraw the legal tender status at some point in the future and following a timely announcement. (2/2)

@BedrosGesaratsi Thanks for your question @BedrosGesaratsi. Indeed, the banknotes from the first series will remain legal tender and can continue to be used as a means of payment and store of value. (1/2)

Together with national supervisors, we are implementing a common methodology for the supervision of smaller banks. Learn more about how this harmonised approach improves supervision and creates a level playing field across the euro area https://t.co/AffdClBLYq https://t.co/I91IZ4UZEJ

Recovery plans are an important tool to help banks overcome a crisis. Based on experience gained from our regular review of banks’ recovery plans, we share best practices to help them improve their plans further. Learn more https://t.co/o2vQ8F5384 https://t.co/sCEEJY8rKL

House price growth in the euro area is accelerating. Although there are still no signs of a credit-fuelled bubble building up, geographical differences in house price developments and mortgage lending are pronounced. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/taJeFkOYyj https://t.co/8feCiU6p0k

For banks to manage risks and adapt to an ever-changing environment, sound governance is vital. With this in mind, we have identified four areas where banks need to make improvements. Find out more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/WurZUaDAXq https://t.co/lnHjpWAm4v

Euro Area Securities Issues Statistics (June 2018) https://t.co/YIv4bQptRV

Since 2013 the amount we as consumers have been spending has contributed significantly to the growth of the euro area economy. For details, see the Economic Bulletin article on private consumption and its drivers in the current economic expansion https://t.co/BAIn5p1yVl 8/8 https://t.co/1IjH2VXCZm
Lower interest rates have benefited those who tend to borrow more than they save. As this group typically consumes more than net savers, this supports consumer spending overall. 7/8

Furthermore, despite exceptionally low interest rates, overall household net interest income has hardly been affected. While interest earnings have declined significantly, interest payments have also decreased considerably. 6/8 https://t.co/1ptluHCV3K
The steady increase in consumer spending in the euro area since 2013 has been accompanied by a gradual decrease in household indebtedness. 5/8 https://t.co/U0i4LGHgsr
The ECB’s monetary policy has also contributed to a modest increase in household net wealth in all income brackets, more so for lower income households. 4/8 https://t.co/JXcC4tQvPk

Rising household income is largely attributable to lower unemployment, in particular among households with lower incomes. ECB monetary policy has contributed to this by stimulating the economy, which supports growth and employment. This has also reduced income inequality. 3/8 https://t.co/kikhtWOcMR

Indeed, the increase in how much we are spending is largely due to rising household income and wealth, and other factors such as the drop in oil prices which has left more money in the pockets of euro area households. 2/8 https://t.co/aa4KVVAHh7

(THREAD) We as consumers in the euro area have been spending more since 2013. How much we spend, on necessities (e.g. food, healthcare, rent) and non-necessities (e.g. electrical appliances, holidays, restaurant visits), is a good way to measure households’ economic wellbeing.1/8 https://t.co/PeClG9vsVL
